last_post.content:
Native Americans are asking The Apache Software Foundation, "…to take the necessary steps needed to express the ally-ship they promote so deeply on their website, to act in accordance with their own code of conduct, to “be careful in the words that [they] choose”, and change their name."

It'll be a big change, but IMO one that's necessary and overdue.

https://blog.nativesintech.org/apache-appropriation/

#OpenSource

Humanity has historically eaten 6,000 plants; now we eat mostly NINE: This is a great (scary) story from Bloomberg on how global diets have converged on a few crops in a few decades – with many alarming implications. Well told (super smart graphics!) #food #climate
https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2022-global-diet-homogeneous-food-security-risk/?cmpid=BBD010523_prognosis&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_term=230105&utm_campaign=prognosis&leadSource=uverify%20wall

title: Separated Bike Lanes Means Safer Streets, Study Says

last_post.content:
Never forget, a 13-year study of a dozen cities found that protected bike-lanes led to a drastic decline in fatalities for all road users.

ALL ROAD USERS.

And painted bike-lanes? No safety improvement at all. As for sharrows, it’s safer to NOT have them.

Via @Streetsblog, read article linked below.

https://usa.streetsblog.org/2019/05/29/protect-yourself-separated-bike-lanes-means-safer-streets-study-says/

#bikelanes #bikes #cities #sharrows #infrastructure #urbanism #cars

I'm teaching "NLP for Cultural Analytics" at UW Linguistics this quarter, and I thought I'd share my reading list for the course.

https://maria-antoniak.github.io/teaching/2023-nlp-ca

Lots of usual suspects from the Journal of Cultural Analytics, but also pieces from NLP and computational social science. Thinking back to an earlier thread on "what even is cultural analytics," you can see from this list my perception of the field (or maybe just what I'm in the mood to read right now).

#DigitalHumanities #CulturalAnalytics

This thread explains the {quartodon} R 📦 (see https://quartodon.opens.science).

The #rstats quartodon 📦 allows you to post a Mastodon thread from a plain text file (e.g., a blog post from a Quarto, {blogdown}, or {distill} website, another Quarto or R Markdown file, or just a plain text file).

This effectively allows you to post blog posts to Mastodon in a thread of toots 📑➡️🪄➡️🐘🐘🐘

🧵1/10

The @DecentSocial #unconference is for those building decentralized social networks across a number of different protocols, coming up on Feb 11th.

It will be online only and cover timezones around the globe.

More details on the website https://decentsocial.net -- please do use the #DecentSocial tag to follow along, suggest topics, and help plan the unconference.

title: Analysis: Which countries are historically responsible for climate change? - Carbon Brief

last_post.content:
Who is responsible for global heating and the climate emergency? Who made it happen?

As you can see from this video, the U.S. is *by far* the country most responsible for poisoning the atmosphere with CO2.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6zP0L69ielU

In recent years, China has been catching up, BUT — we need to remember that they are building all those factories and container ports and roads and mines and airports so they can feed the obscenely huge demands of U.S. consumers.

So, who should pay for climate mitigation, adaptation, and reparations? Obviously, the U.S. must step forward and take the lead. Think it will happen? 🤣

#ClimateCrisis #ClimateJustice
https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-which-countries-are-historically-responsible-for-climate-change/

title: CNET Is Quietly Publishing Entire Articles Generated By AI

last_post.content:
This is terrible.

"CNET, a massively popular tech news outlet, has been quietly employing the help of "automation technology" — a stylistic euphemism for AI — on new wave of financial explainer articles, seemingly starting around November of last year."

It's more terrible b/c "lack of transparency" than "should not do" (who are we kidding; AI has and will replace content generators, even if that means one curator/reviewer is left to double-check the AI output).

https://futurism.com/the-byte/cnet-publishing-articles-by-ai

title: GitHub - skywalker023/sodaverse: 🥤🧑🏻‍🚀Code and dataset for our paper - "SODA: Million-scale Dialogue Distillation with Social Commonsense Contextualization"

last_post.content:
#COSMO is now available on #huggingface
and a chat_with_cosmo.py is available on #github. So i could test this one on my laptop.

COSMO was trained with SODA, a dataset with "social commonsense" and is "only" 3B parameters.

It is not trained to answer questions like #chatgpt , so have right expectations.

But it is really a nice companion...but this conversation got a bit scary 😂

Try yourself:
https://github.com/skywalker023/sodaverse

#ml #ai

Museums and herbaria contain thousands of person-years of specimens that biogeographers often deem "unusable" because they are imprecisely georeferenced. I'm happy to report a simple method for including them in species distribution models and other methods! Please feel free to ask for a reprint, as GEB open access charges were exorbitant ($4400!).

https://doi.org/10.1111/geb.13628

This website provides the full back archive of BYTE magazine, all 23 years of it from 1975 to to 1998. It's a treasure trove of vintage tech and nostalgia, not even Archive.org carries all the issues.

The site actually focuses on old Apple magazines, but has also PC magazines and other resources on the history of microcomputing.

https://vintageapple.org/byte

#retrocomputing #magazines

@jayatid @jthandy @ananth @benn umm, not sure, wasn't around back then, but I think this blog post by Fivetran from 2017- about "The Modern Data Pipeline"- has most of the core elements of what we consider the MDS and is the earliest reference to the core ideas of it as "modern" that I am aware of: https://www.fivetran.com/blog/the-modern-data-pipeline

The consumption layer is only mentioned in passing (which makes sense given the author),

Today marks 1 year since the release of Quasiflock, a #GenerativeArt 3D animation of mine, which triggered a few pretty dark months in my life due to the completely unexpected backlash & escalations (via Twitter DMs/email), subsequently leading me to seriously question sharing my opensource work & thoughts for the first time in >20 years... Filed under life lessons!

Anyway, I still love this piece & absolutely loved learning a ton things whilst working on it (this 2022 remake of the 2006 original was also my first larger #ziglang & #WebAssembly project). More info & variations on the project site (choose "open" to view fullscreen, scroll down the page for variations...)

https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/slug/quasiflock
